Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Cartographic Design for Public Communication of Environmental Information

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation project investigates how maps have been designed and used by the mass media in stories about environmental issues, and what aspects of map design prompt map readers to share these maps on social media. Scientists and science communicators face the challenge of making environmental issues relatable, tangible, and understandable for a broad audience. Maps and other graphics are a powerful way of communicating such issues to the public as maps can help visualize impacts as well as mitigation and adaptation strategies to the public. To date there has been little specific research in cartography focused on how maps with environmental science are produced, reproduced, and shared across a wide range of media, social media, and government agency outlets. The connection between what information is made public, and how, is not well understood, yet has broad significance to science and society for environmental mitigation and adaptation efforts. The results of this research will be shared directly with scientists and science communicators and stands to benefit society by helping to provide clear and transferable guidelines for designing maps for public understanding and dissemination.

Maps are used ubiquitously to illustrate environmental change. Few studies in cartography, however, have focused on the specific issues associated with cartographically communicating environmental change related to the complexity, uncertainty, and multi-dimensionality of the issues. Additionally, within the cartographic research community, there has been a recent push to focus on context-specific maps and on maps that matter for social and environmental issues. This project uses a mixed methods research design to answer four broad questions: (1) What organizations design environmental change maps for the public in the United States? (2) What patterns emerge from evaluating the content and cartographic design of these maps? (3) What are the communication goals of environmental change mapmakers and how are these goals reflected in the map and design decisions? (4) What aspects of cartographic design increase map readers' likelihood to share these maps on social media? The project integrates content analysis, interviews, and survey methods to examine patterns related to where and how these maps are produced, what content and cartographic design they employ, how design decisions are made for communicating to a wide audience, and what aspects of cartography of environmental change maps lead map readers to share these maps more broadly. Qualitative and statistical analysis will be used to assess and synthesize these results. Findings will provide a comprehensive assessment of cartographic design for better communicating environmental change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This doctoral dissertation project investigated how climate change maps are made by the media and government agencies and the potential impact of framing of maps has on affective responses. The NSF DDRI grant provided resources to conduct research including interviews, transcription services, hiring an undergraduate research assistant, travel to set up a project on emotional responses to map design and framing, and travel to better understand how maps are designed and used across the climate change communication and negotiation communities. Through this research, Fish was interested in understanding how design decisions are made by cartographic experts when they communicate complex topics to public audiences, the ways in which those decisions are employed (or not) within a larger variety of maps, and whether design and framing affects emotions of map readers. There were four key components to this research. 

In the first component, as the co-PI, Fish conducted interviews with expert cartographic designers at media organizations and government agencies whose goal is to communicate to the public. This component forms the central methodology of two manuscripts. In the first, Fish evaluated design decisions of expert mapmakers. Results illustrate that storytelling is a key way to bring audiences closer to climate change, help them relate with distant effects, and allow mapmakers to make decisions about what to include and how to design map elements in conjunction with the rest of the story. This storytelling decision-making structure allows cartographers to decide what data to include, what scientists to call, what questions to ask scientists, and how the map will be designed including the use of color, metaphors, layout, and marginalia elements. The second manuscript evaluates the aspects of design which are employed within climate change maps authored by these experts. This paper investigated how the media balanced the use of cartographic conventions with new and novel designs possible now with the web. This result is contrasted with how government agencies design maps which intentionally are familiar designs which do not employ novel elements such as interactivity, drone footage, or virtual reality.

In the second component of this research, Fish collected, with the assistance of four undergraduate research assistants, 242 maps of climate change. With support of the NSF, Fish employed an undergraduate research assistant, Ryan, who coded these maps to understand their content and design. Ryan also helped in the final visualization of many of the results from the analysis of the maps with his expertise of D3 a JavaScript library. The results of this component of the research illustrated that 1) there were similarities and differences in design across a wide range of producers of maps, 2) maps of climate change are produced by a far smaller set of producers than publishers, and 3) some of the best maps are those which incorporate novel designs. 

For the third component, Fish attended the UN Conference of the Parties in Bonn, Germany. Results of this component have provided a new way to view cartography: as a translational discipline for the Anthropocene. Through her observation of the negotiations and conversations with negotiators, it was clear that while maps are not used in this space, storytelling and sharing local impacts with others can break down barriers between scientists, policymakers, and the public. Specifically, Fish drew on conversations dominated by the host nation of the conference, Fiji, for Talenoa, or the need to tell personal stories about the impacts and effects of climate change. Maps are one type of storytelling device and offer one way in which to translate knowledge, communicate across people, and tell real stories.

In the fourth component, Fish started initial data collection of affective responses to climate change framing around maps. This is a collaborative project with Dr. Amy Griffin at RMIT University where they are evaluating affective responses to how maps of climate change are framed in congressional reports. Through the NSF DDRI they were able to create a protocol and begin initial data collection. Preliminary results indicate that emotion recognition software is able to identify affective responses in map readers. They are continuing collecting data to see whether there is a difference in affective responses to different emotional framing of maps.

Finally, results were disseminated through publications and presentations in academic conferences both in the United States and abroad. In addition, through this research Fish was able to incorporate insights into teaching sea level rise which were incorporated into a day organized by Penn State geographers to introduce middle school girls to geography. Finally, findings from this project have been incorporated in undergraduate courses on human-environment geography, GIScience, and cartography at both Penn State University and University of Oregon.
